column1: What percentage of valid votes will the Luiz Inácio Lula da Silva win in the first round of the 2022 Brazilian presidential election?
column5: ['Less than 41.0%', 'Between 41.0% and 44.0%, inclusive', 'More than 44.0% but less than 47.0%', 'Between 47.0% and 50.0%, inclusive', 'More than 50.0%']
column6: ['Leader Entry/Exit', 'Elections and Referenda', 'Non-US Politics']
Updated forecast based on latest polls

The AS/COA aggregated poll shows Lulu predicted to win 45% of the vote, so I updated my forecasts to reflect this. I am wary of the fact that the individual polls which make up the aggregate contain varying figures.
I adjusted again because he is projected to win and the two previous campaigns were he took the 1st round and ultimately won, he had 46% and 48% respectively.

I bumped "less than 41%" down because current reporting shows Lula with at 7.9 point lead, giving him a projected 44% hold on votes and Bolsonaro 36% (https://www.reuters.com/world/americas/front-runner-lula-close-outright-win-brazil-election-2022-10-01/). I also moved the "More than 50%" estimation up because some outlets project that he could win outright in the first round. However, I kept this probability low because he has never won in the 1st round in any of his previous campaigns.
The latest polling updates indicate increased momentum for Lula, with an outside possibility of a majority. Updating forecast accordingly.
Lula is very much surging in the pools, although I still remain a little skeptical that he will be able to clear above 48%

According to the AS/COA polling, Silva has increased to 45% whereas Bolsonaro has increased to 37%. Other polling suggests, according to Washington Post, that Silva may have enough approval to win more than 50% of the vote such that there isn't a runoff election. In fact, "A survey released Thursday by Datafolha, Brazil’s most influential pollster, showed Lula’s support right at 50%" (Washington Post). However, I heard from one group of people that Silva did poorly on the debate. As a result, I have shifted my predictions to reflect a greater change of being at 50% inclusive and at more than 50%. And decreased being at less than 41%.
I still am not finding polls where in the first round of voting, da Silva gets over 50%. Appears that voter intent is up from 41% to 44% with some outliers at 47%. Question ends tomorrow.
Datafolha, Brazil’s most influential pollster, has Lula at 50%- https://news.yahoo.com/lula-outright-brazil-win-sight-221904836.html
Deadheat in polls in mid 40s vs upper 40s. I'll split evenly.
Based on opinion polling data on 29th and 30th Sep, which shows Lula's share steadily increasing

Based on recent news articles like the one from the Financial Times (https://www.ft.com/content/c307c10a-03b2-4c92-bc7e-4d98a8b5a593) and their polling, I am increasing my probability for the 44%-47% option - there seems to be some coalescing around this range for a variety of pollsters. Conversely, I reduced my probability for 47%-50% and more than 50% because not many pollsters are forecasting that high - with The Economist's poll increasingly looking like an outlier (https://www.economist.com/interactive/brazil-2022).
Incumbent advantage

Polling places Lula at 46-50% of valid votes right now (2 days before 1st round of elections).Historically the last week is really bad for frontrunners, but that effect hasn't shown itself in polls yet.It can manifest through absent voters - which tend to be from lower income demographies that currently poll favorably to Lula.The other historical note is that a large percentage of brazilians tend to vote to one of the two leaders to "avoid wasting a vote-", and I believe (from rejection stats and by what I know about Bolsonaro's supporters) that most people who change their vote in this way will flock to Lula.
Updated based on two considerations: 1. New poll results which indicate that Lula da Silva is projected to get 46% of the votes; 2. Increase in negative news on Bolsanaro from Genial/Quaest poll.
looking at more polls.

Since Brazil has a two round system, I think it is very unlikely that Lula will win more than 50% of the votes, but his recently surging polls, as well as the argument made in the comments about voters for candidates who are unlikely to win shifting to Lula, has swayed my predictions.

Last polls presented a 50% of valid votes for Lula (2% error margin). Valid votes includes not only blank votes but also indecisive in the research methodology. Given the chances of winning in the first round materialized, there is a tendency of voting shift from less popular candidates (Ciro - 7%) and Tebet (5%) to either Lula or Bolsonaro. Because Ciro voters that change their vote are much more likely to vote for Lula (as they are left-wing candidates), and Ciro has more votes, I believe there is a high chance the Lula wins in a margin of 50% to 50,5% of votes. Also, a major, reliable newspaper publish a polls aggregator, pointing to 52% of valid votes for Lula. Altough there are chances that he got stucked between 48,5% and 49,9%. If I coud estimate a new range, I would say there is a 95% probability Lula will get from 48,5% to 51,5% of valid votes.
Shifting distribution up as lead continues/grows getting closer to the election
I am still very tied, but believe it makes sense not to be too committed to the result
Lula is gaining, some think he could get over 50%
I’m poor but my brain should have made me rich. I was just in the wrong business..
Latest, largest-yet DataFolha poll shows 50% of the valid votes for Lula.
Current polls have da Silva @ 43%

Lula is strong, and Bolsonaro's claims of possible electoral fraud seem desperate and an effort to discredit his lost. I believe now that Lula could even win in the first round but I do not give a high chance to that. I have reduced significantly my forecast that he will get less than 41% in the first round (from 40 to 10%) as Lula seems stronger than I initially thought.
Reflecting recent polling with a conservative margin of error.
Lula's polling is very strong. I have shifted my distribution in his favour.

Updated polls, now showing that Lula may even exceed the 50% threshold to avoid a runoff (https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2022-09-26/lula-rallies-supporters-seeking-outright-victory-in-brazil-vote, https://www.nytimes.com/2022/09/29/world/americas/lula-bolsonaro-brazil-election.html?searchResultPosition=1)

the trends are shifting a bit, but most polls are in the range of 47-50
i've seen the last polls and Lula seems to be stuck at 46% with no big events happening from now until Sunday

The latest election forecast put Lula with 48% of votes, with a 2% margin of error. I have therefore reduced the probabilities at the lower ends and increased the probability between 47-50% as well as more than 50%. Brazilian newspapers predict that the results will be constant and don't expect big changes so close to the first round.

Recent polls show Lula at 47%. Assuming this might be less on the actual polling date because it's easier to take a poll pre-election than to actually ensure people show up to vote on election day. https://www.reuters.com/world/americas/lula-remains-ahead-bolsonaro-brazil-election-looms-poll-2022-09-26/

The Economist updated this report: https://www-economist-com.ezp-prod1.hul.harvard.edu/interactive/brazil-2022 . About 3% points higher for da Silva than others: https://www.as-coa.org/articles/poll-tracker-brazils-2022-presidential-election and https://www.pollingdata.com.br/
Th Economist forecasts predict Lula at 48%
Latest polls show Lula possibly winning without a runoff. The IPEC poll, showing Lula at 52%, interviewed 3000 people in person. FSB poll had Lula at 48.
vote intention has been growing a little in the past week
Polling within the country suggests that Lula's support is coalescing. https://www.ft.com/content/ac7a3925-f315-417a-b550-9b741f1f9feb
Updating based on the reading of political movements and results of Lula's strategy to convene undecided voters. That is further confirmed by the recent thursday 22 polls.
https://www.pollingdata.com.br/ Updated polling data shows spread from polling data is 40-48%, and da Silva has topped 44%

Luiz Inácio Lula da Silva has not yet polled greater than 50% and it seems more likely to be that de Silva might have an early lead and Bolsonaro as the incumbent might increase his lead closer to the election as the incumbent.

We now know that Lula has 47% of first-round vote, Bolsonaro 33% according to a poll. https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2022-09-23/lula-s-support-puts-first-round-win-back-in-play-datafolha-says?leadSource=uverify%20wall
Most polls suggest Lula securing 44%, and likely to get undecided voter due to the anti-incumbent factor.
Many polls continue to suggest that Lula is likely to win but going over 50% looks a little bit unlikely
New forecasts are showing a greater chance of Lula winning in the first round, with some prominent Brazilian leaders announcing their votes in him.
Currently, Lula is polling at 44% of the vote which was a result of a steady rise over the past week from 41%.
According to polls shared by several main news outlets, Lula de Silva is currently leading the race with 50% of the preferences.

Historically, Brazil has seen two rounds in presidential elections with two top contenders going to the second round. Voter's preferences at this stage and debating performance of Lula suggest that he is strongly likely to maintain the current lead, thus my probability assignments.
I have leveraged the following reference - https://www.economist.com/interactive/brazil-2022 - and was intending to account for the 95% confidence interval by keeping ~2.5 on either extremes and diet
The polls show a declining trend for Lula and a rising one for Bolsonaro. But still, he has a fair chance of going over 41%.
Recent polling from Reuters suggests Lula increasing his lead to around 44%.
Polls are between 44 and 46%
I slightly changed my forecast - recent reports seem to point out that Lula is likely to win over Bolsonaro, which I forecast initially, but fewer percentage points than I assumed.

Most polls I've seen have Lula hovering around 45% of the vote; however, with conversations around election integrity, Bolsonaro's willingness to accept the election results if they don't go his way, etc., I'm not convinced it's going to be a clean or easy election. I also don't think it's likely that Lula receives a simple majority (50%) to avoid a runoff.
Met with team

I have assessed the probability based on two factors: 1. Looking at some of the latest poll figures (showing that Lula Da Silva), which predict him to win 43% of the votes; 2. General % of votes received by the leading candidates in the first round, usually below 50%.

Current polling suggests that Lula's support is currently in the range of 42%-47%. Lula is on an upward trajectory according to the polls, increasing the likelihood that he may surpass 47%. However, the accuracy of polling is in Brazil is a future question to consider.
According to polls, voting intention for Lula da Silva is around 45-47%, with only 2 weeks left for the elections.

- A) due to the unpopular opinion for the former president. Brazilians do not support him (mismanagement of covid-19, inequality, rising prices, poverty) and after years of presidency, they would like a less right-wing president. Lula was seen as the people's president, he established broad social welfare programs and so I imagine, after Bolsonaro's experience, he will have better results.

To make an assessment I looked the outside and inside view: at 1) the vote share for candidates that win the Brazilian presidential election from Lula to Bolsonaro, 2) vote share for Lula during his previous wins, and 3) current polling. While there are more data points I could have looked at-for example the trend in polling before the election and the vote share in the election itself, I made my forecast based on these.

Polls show that a very small percentage of voters (8%) haven’t decided their votes yet or will vote blank (no candidate). 90% of voters say that they have decided on their vote more than one month ago. Lula hasn’t had more than 48% of the votes since May and had been falling slightly since the beginning of the campaign (mid-August). The latest poll (published today) showed that Lula increased from 45% to 47%.

The elections are coming up in 2 weeks, and according to news articles most voters are decided on their vote. Looking at historical data, no President has secured a clear majority since 1998, falling between 42% to 46%. I used this as my anchor and then looked at polling data to see how Lula is performing. Most polls such as Bloomberg and the Economist place him between 44% and 48%, increasing from close to 41% on 9/13. Taking the average of these polling numbers, I think the 44% to 47% range is most likely.

Rationale: Looking at historical data 3 of the past 5 first round elections have been in between 44 - 47% of the vote. While Lula had less of the vote in recent days it seems like he has gained more and more of the popular vote with popularity reasoning. Looking at Lula's previous numbers he won 46 and 48 of the vote. While he is now running for reelection against an incumbent these are helpful to show he was popular and increase in the number of votes he received.
Polling data published on 9/21/22 showed that Lula's support has grown slightly. He is forecast to win 47% of votes with a 2% margin of error.
Most polls have Lula getting between 42 and 49% of the votes in the first round. I believe Lula will benefit from a wider pendulum swing towards the left-of-center politicians in Latin America.
The latest aggregated data from The Economist continue to show an increase.
Updated polls from Reuters

On 9/1, Lula de Silva had a 13 percentage point lead over Bolsonaro where 45% of voter support was with Lula against 32% for Bolsonaro. The percentage points for each of the candidates will be a bit lower given that there will be more candidates during the first round compared to the second round. Additionally, according to AS/COA, on 9/13, Silva was polling at 41% and Bolsonaro was polling at 37% but increasing in percentage points. The data shows as though they are converging and so I think they will both end up hovering around 40-43%.
Updated based upon updating polling

Lula is polling around 41-48% according to different polls. I choose a mid-point between them as the prior given that elections get more volatile towards the end of the campaign and his opponent, which has been trailing since the beginning, might gain more votes as undecided/Blank voters began to switch to a candidate.
New polling shows Lula continuing to pull ahead. Latest from Reuters has Lula's 1st round at 47% and Economist's update is at 49%

It is getting closer and this reference has de Silva at 42-43%. Colleagues also giving this class more weight than others. https://www.pollingdata.com.br/ Adjusting like a superforecaster to the wisdom of the group.

My rationale is the following. 1. I take as a base rate the average of polls published by the Economist as of September 21 (49%)(https://tinyurl.com/359kp3tv) 2. Although Bolsonaro has grown in preferences, I observe that Lula has maintained a stable preference. In other words, Bolsonaro's growth has come at the expense of the undecided. 3. Additionally, I have a hunch that there is a hidden vote in favor of the change. The election is polarized in two. A third candidate is not seen to break this balance, and Bolsonaro will receive a higher percentage of the punishment vote than the polls expected. Same dissent that ironically catapulted him in 2018.

- There seems to be a lot of uncertainty - the polls i've been able to find all have different views on how close Bolsonaro is (e.g. <10% likely to win in Economist poll, 33% on Betting, 42% on Futuur) - so I have a fat tailed distribution

I hope I am not getting anchored to the current forecasts (by the BBC etc.), but a range of 41% to 47% for Lula seems likely. However, since the right is gaining traction, if this continues, I will have to update.
3 polls show that, as of Sep 19, Lula has an average vote of 45%, with an increasing trend.

I cross-referenced several sources on polling data (incl. Economist poll of polls: https://www.economist.com/interactive/brazil-2022) , looked at current events related to Brazil, and integrated wisdom from my teammates. I treated polling averages as an outside view, and updated based on current events.

I read 3 latest polls result and the average by Sep 19 was 45%, with an increasing trend (while Bolsonaro's trend is decreasing). As polls get closer, those undecided voters will make decisions and I believe more people would vote for Lula.

Going through the past data for Brazil's round 1 elections, the top 2 candidates (irrespective of who eventually wins) usually receive 44-35% of the vote share each. So, Lula alone receiving more than 50% votes is highly unlikely. This also puts the highest probability of the vote share being in the top 2 buckets. Additionally, going through the current poll predictions for this specific election predicts Lula will get ~40-45% of the vote share. This strengthens my confidence in this estimate.

Voter intention for Mr Lula has not go down 41% since Aug 8, according to Bloomberg. On the other hand, it is expected to have a second-round of the Brazilian presidential election (that is, Mr Lula will not get more than 50% in the first round), because there has always been second rounds in presidential elections in Brazil since 2002.
Given new opinion polls, the chance of Lula winning in the first round got bigger
Adjustments based on discussion with colleagues
There has been an upward trend for Lula, but we must account for uncertainty.

When googling the most recent polls, the forecasted results for the first round are 47% of votes for Lula, with a 2% margin of error. Therefore, for a confidence level of 95%, we expect that Lula will actually get between 45% and 49% of the votes in the first round in 95% of the cases. To account for this uncertainty, I have left 2% that he gets more than 50% and between 41-44% respectively and 48% that he gets more than 44% but less than 47% and between 47-50% respectively.

It will be tight. Lula will definitely be between 47 and 50 for the most part since all polls put him around 48%. However, there are many undecided voters that could go to Bolsonaro who is incumbent (meaning that he has better reach and more tailored comms) and whose voters tend to be a silent majority. There has only been one candidate in the history of post-dictatorship Brazil that has won on first round. Likewise, in my country Colombia, there is always 2nd round so I doubt he'll win in 1st round. I put 1% confidence in 41% or less because while it's almost unlikely, corruption could discount many Lula votes

Both polls and specialist I have talked to have told me that there is a high probability of Lula wining the first round of the election with over 50% of the vote, he is a popular figure and Bolsonaro has not done a great job, so I think it will be expected for Lula to defeat him.

Lula's current polling average, according to most aggregators, sits at 41-45%. I think it is very likely that his actual first round average will come in around that range. However, I am increasingly more confident that his first round result will be higher than 44%. The last few polls released in the last two days (9/20) show him winning more than 45%. It is not impossible that as the election draws nearer, more undecided voters and Ciro Gomes voters will switch to Lula as the possibility of him winning the first round outright grows slightly more likely (even though it would still be a very small chance). The chance of a Lula surge to over 45% is possible, and I am presenting these initial probabilities as a function of that analysis.

Polls have consistently shown Lula to be in the lead with polls in between 40% and 43%, with a reasonable but diminishing gap between him and the next main contender (Bolsonaro) emerging. Bolsonaro has consistently shown an upward trend since November 2021. Given that there are 11 days before the primary election, there is a probability that the gap could close further with support for Lula dropping below the 41% that it is at the time of this forecast.
Looking at averages from AS/COA's polling tracker, I see that Lula has been hovering between 40 and 43 % support, a trend that has held consistently since this past November.
I am following the polls everyday from differentt sources and accounting for error margins.
Updated due to more positive polling from Arko/Atlas and Ipec

Polls seem to show Lula trending in the 46-47% range in the first round, which makes me think that the 44-47% option is most likely, although there also seems to be a similar likelihood of him achieving more than 47% support based on available data.

Former President Lula's current likelihood of winning is pegged at 45% as per one article I read (dated 1st Sept). Given his left leaning attitude, he seems to have greater chances of winning as quoted by most popular media. However, his competitor Bolsonaro also seems to be steadily reducing his disapproval rate (around 1.2% per month) and the gap between their chances of winning seems to be narrowing. Hence, conservatively, I've pegged my first forecast as 65% chance that Lula will win 44-47% votes. I will update this if required after our group discussion and based on new information in the media.

The latest polls show that Lula has a 45% approval rate, which makes me believe that the percentage of votes would be somewhere between 40% and 50%. However there is a much higher probability that the percentage of valid votes is less than 41% or more than 50% since the ranges are bigger.

Lula is very popular and very likely to defeat Bolsonaro. However, Bolsonaro is still a strong figure. If Lula wins more than 50% of the vote in the first round he would win the presidency outright. I highly doubt that will be the case. I give it a 85% probability he wins less than 50% of the votes, and a 40% he will win less than 41% of the vote. I think the most likely scenario is that Lula wins between 41 and 50% of the vote.

I looked at the percentages of valid votes in the first round that Lula received in his past fives elections (17% in 1989, 27% in 1994, 31% in 1998, 46% in 2002, 48% in 2006). In the 41-44% range, I had no data, but assigned a value of 15% because polls are showing this is a tight race with a narrowing gap between him and Bolsonaro.
based on prior polls (aggregated evidence) - lula da silva is usually getting around 40%
Brazil uses a two-round system for presidential elections. The first round takes place on October 1, only 12 days away.

Small adjustments. I am in the minority thinking that Lula da Silva will win the first round by less than 41%, but he still seems to be trending down from 45% while other candidates gain. Will today's news of lower diesel prices energize more support for Bolsonaro? https://www.reuters.com/business/energy/brazils-petrobras-lower-diesel-prices-tuesday-2022-09-19/
I have based these on approval ratings of OS/COA where Lula has stayed over 40% and below 44% since 8th December, even though Bolsonaro's ratings have improved.

Getting to above 50% is important. There seems to be a block of undecided voters trending towards Lula. But he is currently polling under 50%. Bolsonaro's polling seems to have a ceiling of 35% and might not get much higher. If Lula is polling around 44% he has an opportunity to not have to go to a runoff and perhaps the Brazilian voters will be motivated to have a resolution sooner rather than later.
Following the latest opinion polls, there is a small chance Lula will win in the first round, but he will be probably close
Reuters forecasts that Lula is expected to get 42% of the vote on the first ballot but that also shows that Bolsonaro's support is increasing.
I'm basing this off of aggregated polls. It seems like Lula has generally been polling between 40-43%.
following comments online, but not insights (yet)

Most of the reporting is about rising momentum for Lula and efforts from Bolsonaro's campaign to try to narrow the gap. The latest coverage from the Guardian today (9/18) even reported "a possibility" that Lula could win over 50% of votes. This Guardian piece is the only article to suggest such high numbers and most polls have Lula around 42%.
What is the likelihood of elections going into a runoff?

Based on polling data, Lula has an average polling rate of 43-44% (poll dependent). His polls seem to be dropping month-to-month, but not at a significant rate. This would indicate a good chance that he will end up in October within a range of 41-44%.

Based on poll trackers Lula is predicted to have between 39% and 47% of the vote for the first round of the election, as of September 15th. I looked at 4 sources - IPEC (via CNBC), Reuters, AS-COA.org, and DataFolha (via the Economist). Only the results from the IPEC poll results reported a margin of error, which was 2 percentage points. I used these figures to ground my predictions.

I am re-reviewing https://www.as-coa.org/articles/poll-tracker-brazils-2022-presidential-election. If Ciro Gomes were to drop out I estimate half of the votes would go to de Silva. As less voters are becoming undecided, Bolsenaro's performance in polls is rising.
According to U.S. News, Lula was leading in the polls with 45%.

Seven of the most recent election polls indicated first-round polling between 41-46% (9/15 DataFolha: 45%, 9/13 PollingData: 41%, 9/14 Genial Quaest: 42%, 9/18 Globe Elections UN: 46%, 9/15 Veja: 43%, 9/14 Estadao: 44%, 9/14 CNN Brasil: 44%). Adjusting weighting to account for comprehensiveness, source trust, and recency, leads me to a rough mean forecast of 44%.

I consulted polls showing trends in popularity of current President, trends polls for 4 major candidates, political party information, fears of voting demographics, major issues concerning voters of Brazil.
https://www.as-coa.org/articles/poll-tracker-brazils-2022-presidential-election
The last six months of opinion polls seem to have him between 40% and 45%.

Barring a shift in the electorate, the momentum seems to be on Bolsonaro's side. It seems unlikely, In an global situation that is becoming increasing unstable and economically weary, that Brazil would seek to replace its popular head of state for someone who had a controversial history of corruption, at this uncertain time.

In recent polls, more than half of voters who participated in the poll disapproved of the way President Jair Bolsonaro has been running the country. Most people believe the Economy is Brazil's biggest problem, which is what Lula values the most along with social issues. While I do not agree with every poll, I definitely think Lula will win in the first round of 2022 but will most likely receive less than 41% of the vote.

Looking at the polls and taking into account possible abstentions it seems like Lula is currently in the 46-50% range. With less than a month to go, things can move but they are unlikely to move drastically*. Thus, 41% or less doesn't seem too likely. Around 46% we have bins 2, 3, and 4, which seem most probable and then there is bin 5 in the event that the currently undecided voters that do end up voting decide to mostly vote for Lula.

I see polls for Bolsonaro rising while polls for da Silva seem to be on a flatline or slight decline. By 3 week's time, I expect it to be a closer match. Given that Reuters reported somewhere around 44% for da Silva and projecting forward based on poll data aggregates, I would assume the true number to be lower than 44% and closer to the poll projection of maybe 40%. However, there were moments where it seems Bolsonaro was the heavily unpopular candidate because of his performance with COVID-19 handling in his country of Brazil. So I wouldn't be surprised if a candidate garnered a whopping majority (>50%) of the votes. But 3 week's time may be too short for this to happen, if at all. So I'm really uncertain about the first 3 bins and put a tail on the last bin just in case.
This forecast is based on the following facts:
